description:
there is no nudity in this picture. 
@mollyxmillions

The original meme (file ending in 22.jpg) was posted November 8th by
@the_cumming_memesurrection . The banner was from a protest in Portland
that read "We don't want Biden- we want revenge for police murders,
imperialist wars and fascist massacres." The meme edited the banner to say
"We don't want Biden- we want to eat ass and spread anarchy while we spread
dem butt cheeks, shoot motherfuckers who don't eat ass, draw cool ass iron
front logos on everything."

The meme was deleted because the Instagram moderators considered "shoot
motherfuckers who don't eat ass" to be a credible threat so on November
10th an amended meme (file ending in 44.jpg) was posted which read "We
don't want Biden- we want to eat ass and spread anarchy while we spread dem
butt cheeks, still be nice to people who don't eat ass, draw cool ass iron
front logos on everything."

- deleted by instagram, nudity

Tbh, the space QIPOC are given in the multimedia age feels less and less present, more in the margins.

my curly locks and bridged nose swirl and bend to the beat of a Polynesian rhythm - my wide shoulders carry a tradition of being oneself. When I am me, i'm not enough. When I am them, i'm still not enough.

of course a picture taken on my macbook pro (2013) might seem unassuming, but i promise that that veneer of vivid green screen hides a sickened black history - one i more through everyday.

When i step into a space that caters to western ideals of beauty, i expect to be welcomed (i am 1/4 white after all). Instagram proves once again that non-cis, caucasian features are something that is not allowed inside their gated community.

i'm @karaoketc




Sent from my iPhone

hi! my username is @ morrowindowsvista and on my private account, someone
reported and got this post taken down of my top surgery scar healing
progress, which was prefaced by this pimp spongebob meme i hold very dear

pics deleted, but i get how some people are PUSSIES and cant handle that. i
had to find the meme itself and screenshot it for this submissions. also
much love to my trans siblings. thank u for having my back

this meme was initially born out of my interest in the creative relationship between death grips and animator galen pehrson - specifically, i was inspired by the shitshow music video, which opens with footage of pehrson being filmed by his partner (?) while paramedics try to coax any kind of coherent response out of him. i turned to google in hopes of finding some explanation for pehrsonâs condition - did he have a seizure? too much acid? psychotic break? who knowsâ¦ in classic death grips fashion, powerfully unsettling personal experience was presenting alongside performance art without context or explanation. all my research really turned up was this picture of pehrson and zach hill at some porn hub x brazzers event (a picture that i canât find anymore lol). from there, i thought it would be funny to connect this picture with the fact that the two of them shared a directorâs credit for the shitshow video. just as that video was removed from youtube, this meme was instantly removed 2-3 times from instagram before i was able to get it to stick. the message from instagram was basically that my post was not high enough priority to get looked at by a mod. idk if it was the #pornhub, #brazzers, etc. hashtags that i used or what, but fuck the zuck regardless.

-ð (@whistleblower_memes_69k)



i have one other post that was deleted for good, but i could never figure out what it was lol. iâll submit as a response to this email if i can find out which one it was. also, lmk if u want something other than a .jpg. i tried to export as .png, but it didnât seem any higher quality.
Mây friend sent me a photo of this dog from tik tok that looked human like and I wanted to make memes put of it. I made a meme that Iâll link below and instagram noted it as Â« hate speech> enjoy

Name: Kat Sung
IG: @katattack62
contact: katrinaasung@gmail.com
Project name: nsfw
Description: A mosaic of AI generated videos using RunwayML trained on BDSM
Hentai images found online, and BDSM Hentai images mapped on 3D models of
familiar personal spaces. A study of both artistic style and subject and
how AI interacts with these imagined bodies. Instagram deleted both the
videos and images for nudity, which I found was interesting as these aren't
real or complete bodies but the algorithm recognizes them as such.

(I attached a zip that includes the original videos in case you decide to
allow videos)
 nsfw.zip
<https://drive.google.com/file/d/1eJ3xFNXssEJ9ehfbSWLxsfRnS0MG_BHg/view?usp=drive_web>

one another in color, pose, and features.

Thank you!

My username is @veryobviousvulva, I posted this image of my older sister
and I playing in the bathtub when we were children. Neither of us were old
enough to have even grown visible sexual reproductive organs, yet this was
removed three times and almost had my account deleted. Part of my trauma is
that females in particular are sexualized way way way before they even
understand what's happening. I remember when I was 11, my babysitter told
me men were starting to look at me "different" and I asked why and she said
because of my "mosquito-bite sized titties".

-- 
Hope M. Balsmeyer

Iâm instagram user @skeletent. Iâm a trans masc individual who uses the
platform to make memes and other content, primarily content exploring my
own personal identity as a trans person. Several months ago I took this
picture and tried to post it on instagram, as seen below:

Unsurprisingly, Instagram deleted the post and ignored my attempts to
contact them about it. This isnât the first time Iâve had posts of my body
deleted, and as long as I have these âfemale-presentingâ breasts I know it
wonât be the last.

As a trans person, I live in a body that doesnât fit me correctly. When I
have a rare moment of comfort in my skin, itâs something I feel like
sharing- but iâm not allowed to? Itâs unfair of a website like Instagram to
block all attempts at my own self expression because my chest just so
happens to be larger and more âfemale-presentingâ than other individuals.
Itâs suffocating to have my physical form policed by a society that
attaches female gender to my chest.

Anyways, I think this is a cool project and I appreciate you putting out
the call to receive stories and posts from lesser-known accounts. Thanks
for taking the time to read my submission!

Best,
Jesse Quinlan (they/he)

-- 
he/him/his | they/them/theirs

*username: *@natraum
*deleted for:* nudity/sexual content
*statement:* I have always strongly opposed Instagram's content
restrictions, but I think what has bothered me the most as I've started
questioning my gender is that it feels like Instagram is punishing
femininity. Nipples are not (and should not be) gendered, and furthermore,
nudity and sex are a natural part of life. Since reading Instagram's most
recent guidelines surrounding nudity and sexual content on the platform, I
find myself increasingly frustrated, as now the mere mention of sex is
theoretically grounds for deletion. It astounds me that Instagram has not
only stood behind their archaic restrictions, but continued to lock things
down and pretend that nude bodies don't exist.

Thank you for your consideration.

Sincerely,
Nat Raum
she/they

Thank you for this space for reflection and visibility!

Description / info text:

"I mainly share self-portraits on my Instagram page as part of my 
healing process and reconnection with my body and feelings. The profile 
was never created for followers or to impress anyone else, sharing my 
photos is a simple act of becoming visible and vulnerable within my 
healing process to some close people in my life. But mostly, uploading 
photos just means being honest and vulnerable with myself. In 2020, 
Instagram deleted two photos for nudity, even though the photos were far 
from sexualised or offensive. I felt hurt by this censorship, felt again 
that I was not allowed to take up space, that I had to please others to 
be accepted. I decided to share the removal of my posts and Instagram's 
threats to delete my profile as part of the process I'm going through, 
taking back my freedom to take up space again.â

My instagram user name: luu.ma.r

The images are attached, thank you for providing space.

All the best,
Luumaar

account if I post "nudity" again. Apparently having a body is illegal on
instagram.

Model: @dizzie_nova (me)
Photographer: @wyatt_fassell
Hi, I'm Dizzie. I'm a photographer turned model, passionate about psych,
abolition, erotica, and sad love poems. This image was taken down
immediately after posting it. I submitted an error report and reposted it
again. It was not taken down that time. I have since deleted it because of
the new TOS rolling out--out of fear of being deleted and losing my IG base
from which I have friendships, work contracts, funnel OF subscribers for
extra income and book modeling gigs.

My original caption:

"It's hard for me not to wish to change certain things about myself, and my
small chest is one of them. The thing is, I have always found that self
acceptance brings inner peace and outer celebration that is far more
attractive and mesmerizing than any size or shape of me could ever be.
Also, who fucking cares if anyone finds me attractive or not?? The only
reason I care is because I have to make money and it helps me do that.
Value being tied to appearances is an illusion(pretty politics) I am
privileged to maintain now for survival, and it doesn't have to be this
way.
There's so many embellishments we can use to bring even further enjoyment
and pleasure to our embodiment so why waste the little time we have on
Earth wishing our shapes were different / not breaking down the structures
which oppress us? Shout out to latex and flash photography for this
embodied practice of enjoyment and self celebration."

I reposted to add:

"Hi, so I was going to focus on body self acceptance, but then @instagram
took my post down(this image) stating it violates community guidelines
against nudity and sexual activity.
Not only is this *not* a sexual image, it has already
censored my(apparently inherently sexual and sexualized) nipples.
Fuck you and fuck your bots policing women's bodies and self expression.
This exact photo was Not flagged on my male collegue's account. I know I'm
being stalked by bots and overpoliced on this platform. Seriously fuck this
place.
Anyway, back to my original caption..."

Hi, I'm Aurora and I am a photographer living in Denver, CO.
These images were immediately flagged and taken down from my photography
page--which is pretty exclusively commercial-type creative portraits. I
thought setting the age restriction to 18+ would solve the issue, but I am
thinking I should try to change my sex to Male on my profile cause I have
heard that is another potential safguard against being flagged.
It's upsetting that this type of content is being censored, deleted, and
our community members which deserve the most representation and protections
are being deplatformed. The deletion of sex workers and sex positive
content is a political issue, a class issue, and an attack on
representation, inclusivity and progress in a violent world.
The community I have grown with on instagram has been so pivotal to shaping
my worldview with sex positive content, education, and an engaged,
open-minded community. I'll be happy to move to a new platform with all my
favorite creatives. I believe that if we were to listen to the most
marginalized and shape the world based on their needs we would all be
better for it. That's what I want; decriminalization, sex worker
sovereignty, and a life-affirming world for Black Trans and Indigenous
people.

(Note: I made another submission through my modeling account--where my
alias is Dizzie @dizzie_nova)

IMAGE INFO
Model: Hailey Christensen @desirabledigitals
Photographer: Aurora Adams @auroraprophoto
[image: IMG_1480.JPG][image: IMG_1481.JPG][image: IMG_1486.jpg]

Hello,

I'm submitting an image that was deleted from my Instagram account
(laura__lot) this year, seemingly for containing "nudity" (precisely a
printed picture of one female nipple).

here's the description:




*"The Sphinx" is a collage work of mine inspired by Laura Mulvey and Peter
Wollen's avant-garde film "The Riddles of the Sphinx" (1977).The caption I
posted with this image was a quote by Mulvey: "To the patriarchy, the
Sphinx as woman is a threat and a riddle, but women within patriarchy are
faced with a never-ending series of threats and riddlesâdilemmas which are
hard for women to solve, because the culture within which they must think
is not theirs".The picture was quickly deleted from my instagram
account @laura__lot, apparently because it contained one nipple. Unable to
show this work online, I decided to feature it in a book I recently
released.*

Thanks for the opportunity to submit,
Best wishes for the end of the year
Laura Lot
